newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ dollar ends higher on resurgent Australian dlr.
newsitem.headline: NZ dollar ends higher on resurgent Australian dlr.

text.p: The New Zealand dollar shrugged off political uncertainty to close sharply higher on Monday, due largely to a resurgent Australian currency, dealers said.
"The Aussie is just about to breach 82 (US) cents and the Kiwi's being dragged up on the back of it," a chief dealer said.
The Kiwi closed at US$0.7135/42, up from 0.7118/25 at the open, but was unchanged on its Trade-Weighted Index at 67.10.
"It's closing fairly bid. It's broken the 0.7130 level, where we thought sellers were all afternoon," said another dealer.
He said the dollar had dipped slightly on comments by Labour Party finance spokesman Michael Cullen that the high exchange rate would be the first priority of a Labour-led government.
But there had been good buying out of Asia since mid-afternoon which, coupled with stop-loss buying, had seen the Kiwi spike higher.
"We're trading up through quite key levels really," the dealer said.
Nationalist New Zealand First continues to negotiate separately with the conservative caretaker National government and centre-left Labour to form a coalition after the October 12 election.
An indication of which way NZ First will go is widely expected this week.
The dealer said he expected the Kiwi to be sold on either outcome. "And I think it will rally on no outcome."
The shape of the new government and future fiscal policy overshadowed Treasury's December Economic and Fiscal Update, in which it forecast slightly lower government surpluses than previously.
Dealers said the DEFU held no surprises and had little if any impact on the currency.
The Kiwi was seen testing higher overnight in a 0.7120-45 range. -- Matthew Brockett (64 4) 473-3736
